alt_statements.statement: Look, I’m not against clean air and water—we all live on the same planet—but climate policy has to be grounded in reality, not wishful thinking or government overreach. We should focus on practical, cost‑effective solutions and new technology that cut emissions without killing manufacturing jobs or jacking up energy prices for working people. I don’t trust big sweeping mandates or regulations that punish businesses and taxpayers while countries like China keep burning coal. The right balance is protecting the environment through innovation and incentives, while keeping the economy free enough to grow and keep people employed.

I don’t think it’s an either–or between the environment and the economy, because if we wreck the climate, restaurants, tourism, and regular working people like me are going to get hit first and hardest. We should push for strong climate rules that also create good, stable jobs—like in clean energy, public transit, and sustainable agriculture—so workers can transition instead of just being left behind. I’d rather see us invest in greener infrastructure and support small businesses to adapt than keep propping up fossil fuels that only help big corporations short-term.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we put short-term profits ahead of the world we leave our children, and it isn’t pretty. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, with economic growth reshaped around clean energy, conservation, and green jobs rather than fossil fuels and waste. We’re creative enough as a society to build an economy that thrives without destroying creation, and government has a moral responsibility—one I see as deeply Catholic—to protect the most vulnerable people and ecosystems from climate harm.

As someone who’s seen a lot of change over the years and cares deeply about nature—especially the birds and the small patch of garden I tend—I think we can’t afford to treat environmental protection as optional. At the same time, I know people need steady jobs and affordable energy, especially working families and retirees on fixed incomes. Climate policy should push hard for cleaner energy and conservation, but do it in a way that supports workers through retraining, protects vulnerable households from rising costs, and gives businesses time and incentives to adapt rather than simply punishing them.

As someone who works in aircraft manufacturing, I see firsthand how important a strong economy and good jobs are for families like mine, but I also spend a lot of time outdoors and feel a responsibility to protect the natural world my kids will grow up in. I think climate policy should push innovation—cleaner technologies, more efficient designs, and smarter regulations—so we reduce emissions without gutting industries or putting people out of work. Instead of treating environmental protection and economic growth as opposites, we should see them as partners, using market incentives and clear rules to drive long-term, sustainable prosperity. That approach respects both personal freedom and our duty to be good stewards of God’s creation.

As someone who cares about my community’s future and follows the science on climate change, I think protecting the environment has to come first, but that doesn’t mean we ignore economic growth. Instead, we should invest in clean energy, green jobs, and infrastructure that both cuts emissions and creates opportunities, especially in working-class and Latino neighborhoods like mine. Climate policy should make sure that the people who’ve done the least to cause the problem don’t pay the highest price, and that the transition to a green economy is fair and affordable for everyone.

I care a lot about the outdoors and want clean air, water, and healthy forests for my grandkids someday, but I also know that people like me depend on steady work to keep a roof over our heads—literally and figuratively. Climate policy should aim for practical solutions that protect the environment without killing good-paying jobs or driving up costs for working families. We ought to focus on commonsense measures like incentivizing cleaner technologies, improving efficiency, and managing our resources wisely, not heavy-handed regulations that punish small businesses and workers.

As someone who cares a lot about the future I’m going to live in, I don’t think environmental protection and economic growth should be treated as competing goals—real long‑term growth depends on a livable planet. Climate policy should aggressively cut emissions and invest in clean energy, green infrastructure, and environmental justice, especially for communities of color that are often hit first and worst by climate impacts. I’d rather see us accept short‑term economic adjustments than keep propping up fossil fuels and pass the real costs—stronger storms, health problems, and instability—onto my generation.

I think we need climate policies that protect the environment without wrecking people’s jobs or making basic stuff like food and gas way more expensive. I’m not against regulations, but they should push businesses toward cleaner energy and less waste in realistic steps, so regular workers and small places like restaurants can actually adapt. If we invest in cleaner tech and better public transit, that can create new jobs and help the planet at the same time.

I think we should take care of the earth first, because it’s like our home that God gave us, and we have to keep it clean and safe for animals and kids like me. Grown‑ups can still make money and have jobs, but they should do it in ways that don’t make the air dirty or hurt the trees and oceans. If we protect nature now, then when I’m a grown‑up there will still be a nice world where people can work and live happily.

I believe we need a common-sense balance where we protect our air and water without strangling the businesses that keep people working. Climate rules should be practical, phased in slowly, and based on solid data—not political panic—so companies like the ones I work with can afford to modernize instead of laying people off or moving overseas. I’m all for cleaner technology and smarter efficiency, but we should focus on innovation and American energy independence instead of heavy-handed regulations that punish workers and drive up costs for families.

As someone who came from Cambodia to build a better life here, I believe we should protect the environment in a way that doesn’t punish hardworking families and small businesses. Climate policies need to focus on practical solutions like encouraging cleaner technologies, improving energy efficiency, and supporting innovation in the private sector, rather than heavy-handed regulations that raise prices and cost people their jobs. We can be good stewards of God’s creation while still promoting strong economic growth and opportunity, especially for immigrants and working-class Americans.

As a healthcare professional and a father, I see climate policy first and foremost as a public health and family issue, not just an economic one. We need strong environmental protections that aggressively cut emissions, and we should pair them with smart investment in clean industries so workers and small businesses can thrive in the transition. In my view, long‑term economic growth depends on a stable climate, clean air, and healthy communities, so any “balance” that sacrifices those for short‑term profits is ultimately self‑defeating.

As a management consultant and an immigrant from Chile who has seen both economic struggle and environmental fragility, I don’t see climate policy as a choice between protection and growth, but as a mandate to redesign growth itself. We should set firm, science-based environmental limits and then drive innovation, investment, and job creation within those boundaries—using tools like carbon pricing, clean energy incentives, and strong regulations. In the long run, a stable climate is a precondition for a healthy economy, and responsible businesses will adapt and thrive under clear, consistent rules.

I think we should protect the environment first, because if climate change ruins our planet, there won’t be any economy left to worry about. But I also get that people need jobs and money, so I’d rather see us invest in cleaner energy and green tech that create new kinds of work instead of just shutting things down. It seems smarter to spend money now on preventing damage than to pay way more later fixing disasters and health problems caused by pollution.

As someone who has worn a badge for decades, I believe in protecting our home and our people, but also in being realistic about what working families and small businesses can afford. We should invest in practical environmental measures—like cleaner infrastructure, resilient energy grids, and better disaster preparedness—that create jobs and keep communities safe, instead of imposing heavy-handed regulations that kill industries and raise costs. Climate policy should reward innovation and responsible behavior, not punish those who are just trying to make an honest living.

As someone who works in online retail and cares a lot about health, I see environmental protection and economic growth as deeply connected, not competing goals. We should push for strong climate policies that prioritize clean energy, energy-efficient products, and sustainable business practices, because a healthy planet ultimately supports stable jobs, lower healthcare costs, and better quality of life. Government should help businesses—especially smaller ones—transition with incentives and training rather than just penalties, so workers like me aren’t left behind. In the long run, sacrificing the environment for short-term profit is bad economics and bad for our communities.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we put off taking care of things, and the planet is no different—if we don’t protect the environment now, there won’t be much “economy” left for the next generations. I think climate policy should put environmental protection first, but it also needs to support working people and small businesses like my little salon with help to transition—affordable clean energy, grants, and incentives to make greener choices. Economic growth is important, but it should come from cleaner, smarter work, not from cutting corners on the air we breathe and the water we drink.

As a physician, I see every day how health is inseparable from the environment we live in—air quality, heat, and pollution all show up in my patients’ charts—so I can’t accept the idea that economic growth should come at the cost of a livable planet. My faith and humanitarian values push me toward policies that aggressively reduce emissions and protect vulnerable communities, while still supporting innovation, green jobs, and just transitions for workers. We should treat environmental protection as a non‑negotiable foundation and design our economy around it, not the other way around.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because without a healthy planet there won’t be any economy or future for kids like me. But I also get that people need jobs, so climate policies should help create new kinds of work, like clean energy or green construction, especially for families who don’t have a lot of money. If we’re fair about it and listen to everyone, we can grow in a way that doesn’t destroy the air, water, and parks we all share.

As someone who has made a good living in real estate and is grateful for the opportunities this economy has given me, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we can and must pursue both together. Strong climate policies that encourage energy-efficient buildings, green infrastructure, and resilient communities not only protect God’s creation but also create stable, long-term value for homeowners, businesses, and neighborhoods. For me, the right balance means prioritizing environmental safeguards and public health while giving businesses clear rules and incentives to innovate, rather than letting short-term profits dictate our future.

As someone who worked hard my whole life in construction and lives on a modest retirement, I believe climate policy has to protect both God’s creation and people’s ability to make an honest living. We should invest in cleaner technologies and energy sources, but do it in a way that doesn’t crush small businesses, raise bills too high for working families and seniors, or wipe out good jobs. I trust more in local communities, private innovation, and common‑sense regulations than in heavy-handed federal mandates that can hurt the economy. Environmental protection is important, but it needs to be balanced with practical policies that keep America strong and working people secure.

As someone who works in healthcare and sees every day how our environment shapes people’s bodies and minds, I don’t think environmental protection and economic growth should be treated as competing goals. Climate policy should put planetary and community health first, and then build economic growth around that through green jobs, clean energy, and support for workers and small businesses making the transition. Long term, an economy that destroys its environmental foundation is neither ethical nor stable—real prosperity means clean air, safe water, and resilient communities for everyone.

As a teacher and someone who spends a lot of peaceful time outdoors, I feel strongly that environmental protection has to be the foundation of any economic growth we pursue. Without a stable climate and healthy ecosystems, the economy our students will inherit simply won’t be sustainable. That said, I think climate policy should also support good jobs and help communities transition—especially working families—so people aren’t forced to choose between their livelihoods and the planet. Thoughtful regulations, clean energy investments, and support for affected workers can align long-term prosperity with serious environmental responsibility.

At my age, having watched rivers I knew as a girl run lower and summers grow harsher, it’s clear to me that economic growth built on a ruined climate is a false prosperity. We should treat environmental protection as the frame within which all responsible economic activity must fit, not an optional constraint to be bargained away. That means investing aggressively in clean energy, conservation, and green jobs, even if it slows or reshapes traditional growth, because the true economy we bequeath is the stability of air, water, and land our grandchildren will depend on.

As a teacher and a mom, I want my students and my own kids to inherit a livable planet, so climate policy has to put environmental protection first, not treat it as an afterthought to growth. That said, we should be smart and invest in green technologies, clean energy jobs, and school and community upgrades that both cut emissions and create opportunity, especially for working families. Economic growth that destroys our environment isn’t really “growth” at all—it’s just borrowing against our children’s future.

As someone who works directly with atmospheric data and understands the science, I believe we need smart, targeted climate policies that protect our environment without crippling the economy or national security. We should invest in practical innovations—like cleaner energy technologies and improved efficiency—that create jobs and maintain American competitiveness, rather than sweeping regulations that burden working families and small businesses. Environmental stewardship is important, but it has to be balanced with reliable energy, economic growth, and protecting the livelihoods of American workers.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime looking closely at the world through a lens, I can’t pretend the environment is just another variable in an economic equation—it’s the backdrop for everything, including our livelihoods. We should absolutely pursue economic growth, but climate policy has to set firm environmental guardrails so we’re not “growing” in ways that destroy the very places and communities that make life worth living. I’d rather see us invest aggressively in clean energy, green jobs, and sustainable industries than cling to short-term profits from polluting ones, even if that means some disruption and higher costs in the near term.

I believe we need to protect God’s creation, but we also have to be realistic about how new rules affect working folks like me who rely on our cars to earn a living. Climate policies should focus on practical steps—like improving fuel efficiency and supporting cleaner technology—without killing jobs or driving up costs so much that people on modest incomes can’t afford to get by.

I think we should protect nature a lot because I like playing outside, and if the air and weather get worse, kids won’t have safe places to play. Grown-ups still need jobs and money, but they should try to make those jobs help the Earth too, like using cleaner energy and not wasting things. God made the world, so we should take care of it while still making sure families can have what they need.

As someone who works in public education and spends most of my free time in nature, I believe strong environmental protection has to be the starting point, not an afterthought, in climate policy. That said, I don’t think protecting the environment and economic growth are opposites—if we invest in clean energy, green infrastructure, and resilient communities, we can create good, stable jobs while cutting emissions. Local and federal policies should prioritize long-term sustainability over short-term profit, especially for working families and public services like schools that will bear the costs of climate disasters.

We’ve got to be smart about climate policy so we protect the environment without strangling the economy that puts food on the table. I’d rather see market-driven solutions, innovation, and incentives for cleaner tech than heavy-handed regulations that crush small businesses and drive up energy costs. If we unleash private industry with clear, fair rules and let competition work, we can cut emissions over time without sacrificing jobs or personal freedom.

At my age, I’ve seen how much our communities depend both on a healthy environment and on people having steady work, so I don’t think we can afford to treat those as opposing goals. Climate policy should encourage businesses and towns to shift toward cleaner energy and conservation in a gradual, practical way, with support for workers and small communities so they’re not left behind. We have a responsibility, as stewards of God’s creation, to reduce pollution and protect the world our grandchildren will inherit, but we need to do it with common sense, listening to scientists and also to the people whose livelihoods are affected.

I think we should protect the environment first, because if the planet gets too messed up, there won’t be a good future for anyone’s jobs or money anyway. But I also get that people need to work and support their families, so I think we should spend more money and effort on clean energy and green jobs that help the Earth and still let people make a living.

As a dad and someone who works in a business that depends on people driving, I think we’ve got to be smart about climate policy so it protects the environment without crushing working families’ budgets. We should push cleaner technologies and energy efficiency in ways that create good jobs and keep gas and utility prices manageable, instead of sudden rules that make it hard for regular folks to get to work or support their kids. I believe we can balance both by phasing in realistic standards, supporting innovation, and helping workers and small businesses adapt, rather than treating the economy and the environment like they’re enemies.

As someone who works in healthcare and is raising young kids, I think we can’t afford to treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need both, and smart policy can encourage cleaner industries and good jobs at the same time. I support climate policies that set clear, science-based standards and timelines, but also give businesses incentives and flexibility to innovate rather than just punishing them. For me, the priority is protecting our children’s long-term health and future, while making sure working families like mine aren’t crushed by sudden costs or job losses during the transition.

As someone who immigrated from the Philippines and now works in accounting, I see every day how economic stability matters for families like mine—but I also know that without a livable climate, no balance sheet truly adds up. Climate policy should treat environmental protection as a non‑negotiable foundation and then drive economic growth through clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and green jobs, especially for working people and vulnerable communities. We shouldn’t accept the old tradeoff of “jobs versus the planet”; smart regulations and incentives can push businesses to innovate while ensuring that those most affected by climate change and the transition—both here and abroad—are supported.

We need to take climate change seriously, but we also have to protect jobs and keep the economy strong, especially for working people and small businesses. I support practical, gradual measures—like encouraging cleaner technologies, improving energy efficiency, and expanding nuclear and natural gas—rather than drastic regulations that drive up costs and hurt American workers.

As a mom, a retail worker, and someone who cares about my community’s future, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we have to do both. Climate policy should push businesses toward cleaner energy and sustainable practices, but with strong support for workers and families so jobs are created, not lost, in the transition. If we invest in green infrastructure, public transit, and energy efficiency, we can protect the planet my kids will inherit while also building a more stable and fair economy.

As someone working in state government on economic programs and space research, I see every day that long-term economic growth depends on a stable climate and healthy environment, not the other way around. Climate policy should set clear, science-based environmental limits and emissions targets, then give businesses and communities flexible, market-friendly tools and timelines to innovate within those boundaries. We should prioritize investments in clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and worker retraining so that the transition feels like opportunity rather than punishment, especially for families like mine with young kids whose future is on the line.

Working in home health care, I see how extreme heat and pollution already hurt the most vulnerable, so I believe strong environmental protection has to come first, with smart planning to protect jobs and keep costs manageable. We shouldn’t accept the old idea that we must choose between a healthy planet and a strong economy; instead, we should invest in clean energy, public transit, and building upgrades that create good local jobs while cutting emissions.

As someone who’s spent his life in the law, I believe good climate policy has to protect God’s creation without crippling the livelihoods of working families and small businesses. We ought to pursue reasonable, market-driven solutions—like encouraging innovation, cleaner technology, and conservation—rather than heavy-handed regulations that choke off growth. If we’re thoughtful, we can keep our air and water clean, preserve the birds and lands I love to watch on a quiet morning, and still maintain a strong, competitive economy that offers opportunity to the next generation.

I think we’ve got to take climate change seriously and protect the environment, but we can’t just ignore the fact that people need steady jobs and affordable energy. The government should push for clean energy and greener businesses in a way that creates good-paying jobs for regular folks, not just tech people and investors. With the right incentives and regulations, we can grow the economy by upgrading infrastructure, improving energy efficiency, and supporting workers in the transition instead of leaving them behind.

I believe we’re called to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to protect people’s jobs and the strength of our economy. Climate policies should focus on practical, market-based solutions—like encouraging cleaner technologies and conservation—without punishing small businesses or driving up energy costs for families. We need a balanced approach that reduces pollution over time while keeping America competitive and energy independent.

I think we’ve got to protect the environment, but we can’t do it in a way that crushes working families and small businesses. Climate policy should focus on practical steps like encouraging cleaner technology, improving efficiency, and supporting American energy production, not piling on regulations that cost jobs and drive up utility bills. If we’re smart, we can grow the economy, keep power affordable, and still leave cleaner air and land for our kids.

I think we need to protect the environment, but we can’t ignore the realities of working people and businesses that keep communities running. Climate policy should focus on practical, gradual changes—like improving energy efficiency, encouraging cleaner tech, and supporting American jobs—rather than heavy-handed regulations that raise prices and threaten livelihoods. We should be good stewards of God’s creation, but in a way that keeps our economy strong and our families secure.

We need to protect the environment, but we can’t just slam the brakes on our economy to do it. Smart climate policy should focus on practical, market-driven solutions—like encouraging cleaner technologies and more efficient cars—without overregulating businesses and putting American jobs at risk. I believe we can tune the engine, not replace the whole car, by balancing reasonable environmental standards with policies that keep our industries competitive and our workers employed.

As someone who works in real estate and cares deeply about both my community and the environment, I believe climate policy has to protect our natural resources without strangling economic opportunity. We should prioritize market-based solutions, innovation, and incentives for cleaner technologies rather than heavy-handed regulation that drives up costs for businesses and homeowners. Strong, stable economic growth gives us the means to invest in resilience and cleaner infrastructure, so the goal should be policies that make it easier—not harder—for American workers and companies to adapt and lead in a lower-emissions future.

As a father and a working man, I think we have to protect the environment in a way that doesn’t crush the jobs and businesses regular families depend on. Climate rules should be practical and gradual, focused on cleaner technology and efficiency, not on shutting down whole industries overnight. I’m for solutions that encourage companies to reduce pollution while still allowing the economy to grow, so my kids can have both a healthy planet and real opportunities.

I think we should protect the environment first, because this is the only planet we have and my friends and I have to live here when we grow up. It’s okay if some things cost more or take longer to build as long as they don’t ruin the air, water, and animals. Grown‑ups can still make money and jobs by inventing cleaner ways to do stuff instead of just using things that hurt the Earth.

Working every day with living animals in a museum that also preserves pieces of our past, I see how closely our well-being is tied to the health of the environment and the stories we choose to protect. Climate policy shouldn’t treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposites; we should be investing in renewable energy, conservation, and sustainable industries that create good jobs while keeping ecosystems intact. From my perspective, real prosperity means future generations can still experience thriving habitats, clean air and water, and the cultural and natural heritage we’re entrusted with today.

I think we’ve spent too many years putting economic growth ahead of the planet, and it’s catching up with us, especially in communities like mine that already struggle with health issues and limited resources. We need strong environmental protections and serious climate action, and if that means changing how some businesses operate, then government should help workers and small communities transition rather than slowing down the change. Clean energy and green infrastructure can create good jobs, and we ought to invest in that instead of clinging to old, polluting industries. In the long run, there’s no real economic growth on a damaged planet we can’t live on.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because if we ruin the planet, there won’t be any economy left to grow. But I also get that people need jobs and money to live, so climate policy should push cleaner energy and greener tech that can *create* new kinds of work instead of just shutting old stuff down. It might cost more at the start, but if we don’t invest now, my generation will pay way more later.

As someone who works in manufacturing and spends a lot of time outdoors hiking and watching birds, I believe we need a climate policy that protects the environment without strangling American industry. We should invest in practical, market-driven innovations—like cleaner production methods and better efficiency—rather than heavy-handed regulations that cost jobs and raise prices. Strong businesses and a strong economy give us the resources to be good stewards of God’s creation, so the goal should be smart, balanced policies that keep our air and water clean while allowing companies and workers to thrive.

Como alguien que viene de México, trabaja con familias vulnerables y ve de cerca las desigualdades, creo que la protección ambiental no puede seguir viéndose como un lujo frente al crecimiento económico: es una necesidad básica para la salud y el futuro de nuestras comunidades. Las políticas climáticas deben priorizar una transición justa que cree empleos dignos, proteja a los más pobres del impacto del cambio climático y haga que quienes más contaminan paguen más, en lugar de sacrificar otra vez a las mismas comunidades trabajadoras y de color en nombre del “progreso”.

As someone who works hard for a living and sees how rising costs affect ordinary families, I believe climate policy has to protect both our environment and our economy. We should pursue practical, market-driven solutions—like encouraging innovation in cleaner energy and improving efficiency—without crippling industries, destroying good jobs, or driving up utility bills. I value being a good steward of God’s creation, but I don’t think heavy-handed regulations and unrealistic mandates that punish American workers are the right way forward.

As a science teacher and a mom, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals—long‑term prosperity depends on a stable climate and healthy ecosystems. Climate policy should prioritize strong environmental safeguards and rapid decarbonization, while investing in green jobs, clean energy infrastructure, and worker retraining so communities, especially working families, aren’t left behind.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because if we wreck the planet now there won’t be any future economy for my generation to grow up into. But I also get that people need jobs and money, so I’d rather see us invest in cleaner technologies and energy that create new kinds of work instead of just shutting everything down.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because it’s our only home and my generation will be the ones living with the consequences. But I also get that people need jobs and money, so I’d like to see more investment in things like clean energy and green tech that create new kinds of work instead of just shutting stuff down. If we’re smart and plan ahead, we don’t have to choose between a healthy planet and a strong economy—we can build both at the same time.

I believe we need to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to use common sense so we don’t cripple our local businesses and families with excessive regulations. Climate policy should focus on practical, affordable steps—like encouraging cleaner technologies and conservation—without shutting down industries or driving up energy costs for people on fixed incomes. We can protect our environment while still keeping our economy healthy if we work gradually, listen to local communities, and avoid one-size-fits-all mandates from Washington.

As someone who works in finance and compliance and is raising kids who will live with the long-term consequences of today’s choices, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals. We need predictable, science-based climate policies—like clear emissions standards and incentives for clean energy and sustainable investment—that give businesses certainty while accelerating the transition to a low-carbon economy. Growth that ignores climate risk is ultimately fragile and unfair, especially to younger and more vulnerable people, so I favor policies that may demand short-term adjustments but build a more resilient, innovative economy over the long run.

As someone who works in finance and values both long-term stability and social responsibility, I see environmental protection and economic growth as mutually reinforcing rather than competing goals. Climate policy should aggressively reduce emissions and invest in clean energy and resilient infrastructure, while using market-based tools and smart regulation to drive innovation and protect jobs. If we internalize environmental costs and plan ahead, we can grow the economy in a way that safeguards public health, preserves creation, and avoids much higher financial and human costs down the road.

I think we need a balanced approach where we protect the environment without crippling the businesses and workers our communities depend on. Climate policy should focus on practical steps like encouraging cleaner energy and better technology through incentives, not heavy-handed regulations that drive up costs for families and small towns. We can be good stewards of God’s creation while still keeping our economy strong and preserving people’s jobs and way of life.

I think we should protect nature a lot, because I love playing outside and I want clean air and forests to still be there when I grow up. But I also know people need jobs and money, so I think we should make rules that push companies to use cleaner energy and not pollute, instead of just shutting everything down. That way, families can still work and our planet doesn’t get ruined.

As someone who has spent a career nurturing young minds and now thinks often about the world we’re leaving to the next generation, I believe environmental protection must set the boundaries within which economic growth can occur. Climate policy should prioritize rapid decarbonization, clean energy, and public health, even if that means reshaping industries and short-term sacrifices, because a degraded planet ultimately undermines any real prosperity. That said, government should help workers and communities, especially in vulnerable and low-income areas, transition with strong support, training, and green job creation so that climate action is both just and sustainable.

At this point in my life, I think protecting the environment has to come first, because there’s no real “economy” on a planet that’s becoming unlivable. That doesn’t mean ignoring people’s jobs, but it does mean we should be investing in clean energy and conservation, and helping workers transition, instead of clinging to old industries that are damaging the climate. Spending time watching birds and walking in the woods, I see how fragile these ecosystems are, and it’s worth accepting some short‑term economic disruption to preserve them for the long run.

As someone who works in finance, I believe strong economic growth and environmental protection don’t have to be at odds, but climate policy must be grounded in cost-benefit analysis and practical outcomes, not ideology. We should prioritize market-based solutions, technological innovation, and incentives for businesses to reduce emissions, rather than heavy-handed regulation that burdens families and job creators. I support gradual, measured changes that protect our children’s future while keeping energy affordable, maintaining American competitiveness, and respecting individual responsibility and property rights.

As someone who came from Haiti and has seen firsthand how environmental degradation can devastate poor communities, I believe protecting the climate must be the starting point, not an afterthought, in economic policy. We should invest heavily in clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and green jobs so that growth lifts people up without sacrificing the health of our planet or our neighborhoods. A just climate policy must prioritize vulnerable communities—both here and abroad—so that the transition away from fossil fuels is fair, inclusive, and creates opportunity rather than hardship.

I believe climate policy has to protect the environment without crippling the industries that keep people employed and the economy strong. We should back practical, market-driven solutions—like incentives for cleaner technologies in manufacturing and energy—rather than heavy-handed regulations that drive jobs overseas. As a supervisor in metals and minerals, I see how realistic standards and gradual transitions can reduce emissions while keeping American businesses competitive. We have a responsibility, morally and for future generations, to be good stewards of the earth, but that stewardship has to be grounded in economic reality and technological feasibility.

As a conservative small-business attorney, I believe sound climate policy must protect our environment without crippling the economic engine that funds innovation, jobs, and American prosperity. We should prioritize market-based solutions, technological advancement, and incentivizing cleaner energy over heavy-handed regulation that harms small firms and working families. Environmental standards should be realistic, cost-effective, and grounded in solid science, with clear, predictable rules so businesses can plan and invest confidently. In short, we must be good stewards of God’s creation while ensuring that climate policy strengthens, rather than undermines, our free-market economy and national competitiveness.

Como alguien que trabaja en logística y ve de cerca cómo se mueve la economía, creo que proteger el medio ambiente y mantener el crecimiento económico no son objetivos opuestos, pero sí requieren cambios inteligentes. Necesitamos invertir en energías limpias, transporte más eficiente y regulaciones claras que obliguen a las empresas a contaminar menos sin destruir los empleos que sostienen a familias como la mía. Si el gobierno apoya la transición con capacitación y ayuda para los trabajadores y las pequeñas empresas, podemos reducir el impacto climático y seguir haciendo crecer la economía de manera más justa.

I like when we plant trees and keep the air clean so we can play outside and not get sick. Grown-ups should make money and have jobs, but they shouldn’t break the world God made for us. I think we should use smart ideas and new things so we can have both good jobs and a safe place to live.

At my age, I’ve seen how hardworking people, especially in healthcare and other modest jobs, depend on a strong economy to keep food on the table and medicine paid for. I believe we should protect God’s creation and be good stewards of the earth, but climate policies must be practical, gradual, and not crush small businesses or drive up costs for ordinary folks on fixed incomes. I’d support cleaner technology and reasonable regulations that encourage innovation and American energy independence, rather than heavy-handed rules that hurt jobs and raise utility bills.

As someone who works every day making sure people go home safe from their jobs, I see climate policy the same way: protecting the environment is ultimately about protecting people and their kids’ future. I don’t think we should trash local businesses or workers’ livelihoods, but we can’t keep kicking the can down the road either. The right balance is smart, gradual regulations and investments in cleaner technology that create stable jobs, keep communities healthy, and don’t leave working families like mine holding the bag for short-term profits.

As an engineer, I’m very aware that unchecked climate change will ultimately be far more expensive and disruptive to our economy than well-designed regulations today. I think we should focus on market-based tools—like carbon pricing, innovation incentives, and clear, stable standards—that let businesses compete to cut emissions without heavy-handed micromanagement from the government. The balance is investing aggressively in cleaner technologies and efficiency now, while preserving economic freedom and making sure working people and smaller firms aren’t crushed by abrupt or poorly thought-out mandates.

My mommy says the air and trees have to stay clean so I can run and play and not get sick, so I think we should take care of the Earth first. Grown-ups can still make money and have jobs, but they should do it in a way that doesn’t make the sky dirty or hurt the places where kids play.

As someone who has worked hard my whole life and seen families struggle, I believe we need climate policies that protect God’s creation without destroying people’s livelihoods. We should invest in sensible, cost-effective measures—like improving energy efficiency and encouraging innovation in cleaner technologies—rather than heavy-handed regulations that drive up prices and shut down good jobs. A strong economy gives us the resources to take better care of the environment, so the two should go hand in hand, not be pitted against each other.

I believe we’re called to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to protect families’ livelihoods and our community’s economic stability. Climate policies should encourage innovation, responsible energy use, and conservation without crushing small businesses or driving up costs so much that working parents can’t make ends meet. We should focus on practical, market-based solutions, not sweeping regulations that hurt American workers while other countries ignore the rules.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors and cares deeply about the natural world, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we just need to redefine what “growth” means. Climate policy should put strict limits on pollution and habitat destruction, and then encourage jobs and innovation in clean energy, conservation, and sustainable industries so people can make a living without sacrificing the planet. From my perspective, any short-term economic sacrifices are worth it if they protect the ecosystems and species we depend on, including the birds I love to watch.

I believe we need a balanced approach where we protect the environment without crushing the jobs and businesses that keep families like mine afloat. I’m all for cleaner cars, better technology, and less waste, but the rules should be practical, phased in reasonably, and not written by people who’ve never worked with their hands or run a small shop. Climate policy should encourage innovation and energy independence, not pile on costs that get passed down to working folks and make it harder to provide for our kids.

At my age, I’ve watched what happens when short-term profit is put ahead of caring for God’s creation, and it’s the working folks and their kids who end up paying the price. I think we need strong climate policies that put environmental protection first, but done in a way that creates good, stable jobs and helps workers and small businesses transition, not just big corporations. Economic growth that destroys our air, water, and future isn’t real growth—it’s a debt we’re leaving to the next generation.

As someone who runs her own travel accommodation business and has seen firsthand how beautiful — and fragile — our world is, I believe environmental protection and economic growth must go hand in hand, not be treated as opposites. Climate policy should prioritize strong protections for the environment while supporting incentives and clear guidelines that help businesses adapt and innovate, rather than simply punishing them. If we damage the very places people travel to experience, we undermine long-term prosperity; investing now in cleaner energy, resilient infrastructure, and sustainable tourism is both a moral responsibility and smart economics.

As a pilot who sees the planet from 35,000 feet on a regular basis, I’m convinced we can’t treat environmental protection as optional or secondary to growth—it has to be built into how we grow. Climate policy should aggressively push decarbonization and cleaner technologies, including in aviation, but do it in a way that gives businesses predictable rules and time to adapt so we keep good jobs and innovation here in the U.S. If we invest heavily in green infrastructure and research, we can make environmental responsibility a competitive advantage rather than a drag on the economy.

I make my living working with old iron, and I’ve seen a lot of regulations that sound good on paper but just pile costs on small shops and regular folks without making a dent in global emissions. We should aim for cleaner air and smarter energy, sure, but the market and new technology—not heavy-handed government mandates—ought to drive that, so businesses can grow and people can afford to heat their homes and drive to work. Climate policy should focus on practical, cost‑effective solutions like incentives for efficiency and innovation, not blanket rules that cripple the economy or tell people how to live.

We absolutely need to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to use common sense so we don’t cripple our economy or hurt working families and retirees on fixed incomes. Climate policy should focus on practical steps—like encouraging cleaner technology, conservation, and responsible industry—without heavy-handed regulations or sudden changes that drive up energy costs and destroy jobs.

Como alguien que vive modestamente, trabaja en el comercio y ve lo difícil que es para muchos llegar a fin de mes, creo que la política climática tiene que proteger el medio ambiente sin olvidar a los trabajadores y los negocios pequeños. Para mí, el equilibrio está en invertir fuerte en energías limpias, transporte público y eficiencia energética, de manera que se creen buenos empleos y se bajen costos a largo plazo, en lugar de simplemente imponer reglas que encarezcan todo de golpe. Además, las comunidades trabajadoras y latinas, como la mía, deben ser prioridad en esos planes, recibiendo apoyo para capacitación, adaptación y acceso a nuevas oportunidades económicas verdes.

At my age, I’ve seen that when we ignore the environment in the name of “growth,” we just end up paying a bigger bill later—whether it’s in health problems, disasters, or lost livelihoods. Climate policy ought to put environmental protection first, with smart investments in clean energy and green jobs so working folks don’t get left behind. We can grow the economy by building things that last—efficient schools, better transit, cleaner air—rather than chasing short-term profits that tear up the planet. Personal freedom, to me, includes the freedom for my grandkids’ generation to enjoy a stable climate and healthy communities.

I believe we need a practical balance where we protect the environment without crippling the economy or driving up costs for working families. Climate policy should focus on innovation, efficiency, and gradual, realistic changes—like incentivizing cleaner technologies and responsible energy use—rather than heavy-handed regulations that hurt small businesses and jobs. We’re called to be good stewards of God’s creation, but also to protect people’s livelihoods and keep the country strong and secure.

I believe we have a responsibility, as stewards of God’s creation, to protect the environment, but we must do it in a way that doesn’t cripple our economy or burden working families and small businesses. Climate policy should focus on practical, market-based solutions—like encouraging innovation in cleaner energy and efficiency—rather than heavy-handed regulations that kill jobs and raise costs. We ought to move toward cleaner technologies steadily, with careful cost–benefit analysis, so we leave a livable world to our grandchildren without undermining the prosperity that made this country strong.

I think we have to stop treating environmental protection and economic growth like they’re enemies. We should be investing in clean energy, public transit, and greener tech so we can create good-paying jobs while cutting emissions, instead of clinging to old, polluting industries that won’t last. For people like me working retail and just trying to live a stable life, policies need to protect the planet without putting all the costs on working families—big corporations that profited from pollution should carry most of the financial burden. Environmental policy should be about fairness and long-term sustainability, not short-term profit.

As someone who’s active in my community and raising kids who will inherit this world, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need a climate policy that treats a healthy planet as the foundation of a healthy economy. I support strong regulations to cut emissions and protect vulnerable communities, paired with investments in clean energy, job retraining, and sustainable infrastructure so that workers and small businesses aren’t left behind. Environmental justice should be central, ensuring that low-income and marginalized neighborhoods don’t bear the brunt of pollution while others profit.

I make my living keeping big machines running, so I know industry is what puts food on the table, but I also spend most of my free time outdoors and don’t want to see the land or air trashed. Climate policy should set clear, simple rules that protect the environment and our health, but it ought to leave businesses free to figure out the best way to meet those standards without endless government micromanaging. If we focus on innovation, cleaner tech, and fair incentives instead of heavy-handed regulation, we can have both a strong economy and a landscape that’s still worth exploring.

As a business owner and a mom, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need smart climate policies that drive innovation, create good jobs, and keep our kids healthy. I support strong, science-based regulations and incentives that push companies toward cleaner energy and more sustainable practices, while giving them clear, stable rules so they can plan and grow. If we invest in green technologies and resilient infrastructure now, we protect both the planet and long-term economic opportunity, especially for future generations.

I think protecting the environment should come first, because if we ruin the planet, the money and growth won’t matter anymore. But I also think we should help people keep their jobs by investing in clean energy, green businesses, and training so families, especially in communities like mine, aren’t left behind. Climate policies should make big polluters pay more, while helping regular people save energy and money at home.

At my age, having watched rivers catch fire in the 60s and air in our cities become briefly unbreathable, it’s obvious to me that economic growth built on environmental ruin is a short-term illusion, not real prosperity. Climate policy should put environmental protection first as the non‑negotiable boundary within which a fair, innovative, and jobs‑rich economy can flourish—much like the safety standards we long ago accepted in other realms. We should invest heavily in clean energy and resilient infrastructure, not just to avert catastrophe, but to ensure that future generations inherit both a livable planet and a dynamic economy, rather than being forced to choose between them.

We have a responsibility, as stewards of God’s creation, to protect the environment, but we also have to be realistic and careful not to cripple the economy or hurt working families and retirees on fixed incomes. Climate policy should focus on practical, incremental steps—like supporting cleaner technology, better energy efficiency, and smart regulation—without heavy-handed mandates that destroy jobs or drive up utility bills. A healthy private sector and strong economy give us the resources to innovate and adapt, so the goal should be sensible balance, not ideology.

As someone who spent a career in the military and knows how important a strong economy is for national security, I believe climate policy has to protect both our environment and our livelihoods. We should invest in practical, market-driven solutions—like cleaner energy technology and conservation incentives—without overregulating businesses or killing good-paying jobs. I love the outdoors and want to preserve our natural resources, but changes need to be gradual, realistic, and focused on innovation rather than heavy-handed government mandates.

As someone working in the tech industry, I see every day how innovation can drive both economic growth and smarter environmental solutions, so I don’t accept that we have to choose one over the other. Climate policy should set firm, science-based limits on emissions and environmental damage, then incentivize businesses to compete on clean energy, efficiency, and sustainable design. In the long run, protecting the environment is the only way to protect a stable economy, and we should prioritize workers and communities in that transition with retraining, green jobs, and support for those most affected.

As someone who loves being outdoors hiking and watching birds, I feel like a healthy environment isn’t optional—it’s the foundation for any real, lasting economic growth. Climate policy should put strong environmental protections first, while investing in green jobs, public transit, and clean energy so working people, especially in hospitals and other essential jobs, aren’t left behind. We can grow the economy, but it has to be done in a way that protects vulnerable communities, creates fair wages, and makes sure clean air and water aren’t just for the rich.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when short-term economic gains are put ahead of the land, the water, and the creatures that depend on them—including us. Climate policy ought to treat environmental protection as the foundation of any healthy economy, not an optional extra, even if that means slowing or reshaping certain kinds of growth. We should invest in green jobs, conservation, and renewable energy so people can make a living without destroying the habitats and species that make life rich and livable. True prosperity is measured in clean air, safe water, and thriving ecosystems, not just in profits and GDP.
